title.rendered: New Logo and On-air Packaging for TCM Latin America by Injaus Design

content.rendered:
Launched in 2004, TCM (Turner Classic Movies) Latin America is a cable and satellite channel available across Latin America, Spain, and in the U.S.. Owned by Turner, TCM’s programming includes movies and TV series from the 1980s and ’90s — I guess the 1950s are too old to be classics. So if you want a showing of Alf followed by Die Hard, TCM has got you covered. In November TCM introduced a new logo and identity designed by Turner Latin America’s in-house design team, cleverly called Injaus Design.

While the American TCM retains the classic extended wordmark — which is a perfectly nice piece of typography, especially with the inline that was dropped by TCM LA at some point — the Latin American team has opted for something less… classic, I guess. It’s really hard to figure out what associations (if any) it’s trying to trigger. The typography is Art Deco-ish and the shadows could hint at a mid-century aesthetic but the “refresh” C-arrow thing is plain weird and anachronistic. It also doesn’t look good, particularly at small sizes when the arrow makes the “C” look top-heavy.

One nicer aspect of the redesign are the social media banners that showcase an interesting combination of color and typographic palettes that are cool on their own and as a system but also lack a clear reference to the programming, looking more like typography found in B-movie posters.

Again, sorry for the low-res and weird pacing of the on-air look video; there was no official release but it gives you an idea of where the motion package is heading. And it’s not the right direction either, feeling more like Nickelodeon mixed with an old version of TV Land. There is a cheap peel effect and an odd plastic sheen to everything. If the channel’s focus is on 1980s and ’90s I don’t know why they didn’t milk that aesthetic that is so chic right now and instead landed on this somewhat vintage, somewhat modern, and all-around confusing identity.
